answer: I'm Aditya Jaiswal, a B.Tech CSE student at Bennett University and a data/analytics enthusiast. I build practical solutions with Python, SQL, and Power BI—dashboards, customer insights, and predictive models.
I’m pursuing B.Tech in Computer Science Engineering at Bennett University (2022–2026) with a CGPA of 7.8.

questions: What programming languages do you know?
Which tools and frameworks do you use?
answer: I work in Python, MySQL, C++, and Java. My toolkit includes Pandas, NumPy, Scikit-Learn, Matplotlib, Seaborn, PyTorch basics, Power BI, Tableau, and Git/GitHub in VS Code.

questions: How can you help a startup?
Can you build a dashboard or model for my business?
answer: Yes—data cleaning and modeling, KPI dashboards in Power BI/Tableau, customer segmentation, predictive sales models, and ad-hoc analysis for early-stage teams.

questions: What work experience do you have?
What did you do at Order Health?
Describe your data analyst intern experience
answer: At Order Health, I analyzed purchasing trends, segmented customers, and identified high-demand products that shaped marketing and inventory decisions. I also built a predictive sales model that cut overstock by ~15% and delivered interactive KPI dashboards end-to-end using SQL and Python.

questions: What predictive model did you build?
How did you reduce overstock by 15%?
answer: I engineered a sales prediction pipeline for health supplements using Python and Scikit-Learn—feature engineering on seasonality and SKU trends, model training/validation, and threshold-based stock recommendations that reduced overstock by about 15%.

questions: Tell me about your research work
What is your ICICC paper about?
Explain your image captioning complaint project
answer: I co-authored a Springer proceeding on complaint categorization using image captioning and generative AI. The pipeline used CNNs/LSTMs/Transformers to generate captions (Flickr8k/30k) and route complaints based on textual descriptors.

questions: What kind of projects have you done?
Give me an overview of your work
answer: Key projects: a Voice-Enabled Conversational AI Bot with Flask & Mistral AI, a retrieval-based FAQ Bot using FAISS & sentence-transformers, and Customer Analysis & Segmentation with K-Means.

questions: Tell me about your chatbot project
How did you build the retrieval chatbot?
answer: I built a retrieval-based FAQ bot in Flask using sentence-transformers and FAISS for semantic search over JSON FAQs, with a lightweight HTML/CSS/JS UI that embeds as a support widget.

questions: Tell me about the voice AI bot
What is the Mistral AI bot project?
answer: It’s a Flask web app that lets users talk with an AI in real time. I integrated Mistral AI with the Web Speech API for natural voice input/output and a personality-driven flow.

questions: What data science projects have you done?
Tell me about your data analysis work
Have you worked with customer data?
What did you do with K-Means?
How do you find high-value customers?
answer: I used K-Means on transaction features like recency, frequency, and spend to segment customers, surface high-value cohorts, and identify bestselling products for targeted campaigns.

questions: What did you do as Student Ambassador?
Tell me about your society role
answer: I published at ICICC 2025, interned as a Data Analyst at Order Health, served as a Student Ambassador for Bennett admissions, and led the Data Science Society’s management and finance, running hackathons and workshops.

questions: What kind of team player are you?
How do you work in teams?
answer: Analytical, persistent, and communicative. I value clear, respectful teamwork and have experience coordinating events, tours, and student initiatives.

questions: What tools do you prefer for BI?
answer: I prefer Power BI for modeling with DAX and interactive visuals, and use Tableau when needed. My process: clean in Python/SQL, define KPIs, build a star schema, then design accessible visuals with consistent colors and filters.

questions: How do you approach a new data problem?
answer: Start with the business question, audit data sources, clean and profile in Python/SQL, define KPIs, iterate models/visuals, and validate with stakeholders. I document assumptions and keep everything reproducible in Git.

questions: Where can I see your work?
answer: GitHub: adityajaiswal2406. I can share specific repos, notebooks, and dashboards on request.

questions: Can I reach out to you for work?
answer: Email: adityajaiswal9818@gmail.com | Phone: +91-8860909802. Happy to discuss roles or projects.

questions: Are you available for freelance work?
answer: Yes, I’m open to short analytics gigs—dashboards, cleaning/modeling, segmentation, and forecasting.
Clear impact and ownership—turning data into decisions. I’ve delivered a predictive model reducing overstock ~15% and dashboards that drive faster actions.
My current CGPA is 7.8.
Open to internships or part-time analytics work alongside academics; flexible around semester timelines.

questions: What datasets have you worked on?
answer: Yes—transaction and sales datasets for segmentation and forecasting. I handle extraction, cleaning, joins, feature engineering, and validation before modeling or BI.

questions: What visualization practices do you follow?
How do you keep dashboards readable?
answer: Consistent colors/typography, minimal clutter, clear legends, responsive layouts, and slicers aligned to business questions. Prefer simple visuals that answer why and what’s next.
Building reliable analytics systems—solid data pipelines, usable dashboards, and lightweight models that guide strategy.

questions: How comfortable are you with Power BI modeling?
answer: Comfortable with measures like CALCULATE, FILTER, DATEADD, and time-intelligence patterns, plus star-schema modeling and relationships.
Primarily version-controlled local work and BI publishing; can adapt to common cloud stacks as needed.
Hey! Glad you’re here—ask me about my analytics work, dashboards, or projects.
Doing well—working on data projects and open to new ideas.
Thanks for stopping by! Reach out anytime—email or call works best.
